entry.title: Combined summary - soft-fork block size increase (extension blocks)
entry.summary: The issue of the block size in Bitcoin is a topic of debate, with some advocating for larger blocks and others valuing decentralization. One proposal suggests that exchanges could incentivize the use of wallets that support 8MB blocks by charging a fee for 1MB transactions. However, increasing the block size can cause problems for old clients who may not understand the difference between 1MB and 8MB payments. SPV wallets do not face this issue, while fully validating wallets can be updated with a small code change.There is also a tradeoff between security and volume when it comes to block size, with different people having different requirements and comfort zones. The author suggests waiting and seeing if the block size should stay as is or reducing spam, improving decentralization metrics, and relay latency before incrementally increasing the block size as necessary. It is proposed that experimentation with larger blocks can occur without conflicting with those who value decentralization.The argument regarding huge blocks and data centers was originally made by Satoshi, not the person being addressed. The writer of the message had previously written the scalability page for Bitcoin in 2011, which suggested that the core network could scale to much higher transaction rates assuming nodes were primarily running on high-end servers. However, they did not believe that we would reach VISA scale anytime soon, barring some currently unimagined killer app. The author feels that people have been misrepresenting their views and proposes that both scale and security are important within an approximately safe envelope.In an email exchange on June 1, 2015, Adam Back discussed the possibility of reducing spam and waiting to see if fee pressure would take effect, while working on improving decentralisation metrics and relay latency. He also suggested increasing the block size incrementally if necessary, while attempting to find a long-term solution for scaling beyond just volume. When asked about the lead time required to kick the can, there was no clear answer. Back provided a graph that showed how the maximum block size had been in play for eight months, emphasizing the importance of looking at the distribution of block sizes rather than just the average.In another email conversation, a developer expresses concern about updating software to support extension blocks. They argue that payments must be reliable and wallets must be compatible with each other. The developer disagrees with the idea that a Lightning-style approach would work, citing danger, inflexibility, and worse decentralization. They also express concern about using companies as a sounding board and ignoring the opinions of those providing services to the community. Overall, the developer is not in favor of extension blocks or any other contraption that exists purely to work around theoretical objections by Blockstream employees.To sum up, while there are different views on the block size in Bitcoin, the author proposes waiting and seeing if the block size should stay as is or reducing spam, improving decentralization metrics, and relay latency before incrementally increasing the block size as necessary. The tradeoff between security and volume when it comes to block size must also be considered, with experimentation with larger blocks occurring without conflicting with those who value decentralization. It is important to consider both scale and security within an approximately safe envelope.
